awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Human, Machine, and Network Functional, Symbiotic Integration On Neural Systems (Human Fusions)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

This project will develop the foundational plan of an Engineering Research Center (ERC) to form a unique, transformative, and transdisciplinary team that will create, define, understand, and teach the science, technology, ethics, regulatory framework, entrepreneurship methodologies, and societal impact of the rapidly evolving integration of humans and technology. Communication and technology revolutions, such as radio, television, and the internet, have resulted in profound societal changes. The human, however, has basically remained external to the system with technology serving only as a tool. We propose that a conceptual shift toward symbiotic integration of the human with technology will bring the next societal transformation leading to a more connected, global society with new operational models of work, anthropocentric technology, and human-human interaction. We envision a tech-plus, transdisciplinary team of scholars, entrepreneurs, ethicists, and members from partnering institutions (including companies) that will perform convergent research at a new frontier of human incorporation of technology into a sense of self, i.e. a symbiosis between humans and technology. The core is a shift from the current techno-centric approach, where human and technology are separate, to a human-centric technology development paradigm. We seek to shift the societal dialogue from that of a battle between humans and technology (such as artificial intelligence and robotics) to a more productive dialogue of merging the best of humans and technology for the mutual benefit of both.  Symbiotic incorporation of technology requires new interfaces to the human that add multiple sensory connections beyond current audio and visual inputs. This symbiotic relationship will augment human capability with those of technology and networked systems. New, symbiotic technology will radically change the future of work, human learning, human-human interaction, human networks, human health, human capability, and society overall for a safer, more prosperous future. The overall goal is to refine the model sufficiently to be compelling for a sustained research and development effort in an ERC for merging Humans, Machines, and Networks through Functional, Symbiotic, Integration On Neural Systems or an ERC for Human Fusions. Prior significant research shows that the core need of incorporation of technology into a human's sense of self, requires 1) a sense of agency over technology and 2) multi-sensory synchrony with technology. 

Strictly, this project is a planning grant to develop the ERC structure and processes that will rationally evolve the relationship between humans and technology. Methods from the Science of Team Science (SciTS) will be employed to establish relationships between committed, energized stakeholders in this new, transdisciplinary effort in human-technology symbiosis and a strategic plan to grow and establish sustainable research capacity. The objectives of the project are to 1) assemble the expertise to define the transdisciplinary, tech-plus framework; 2) develop a process and the collaborative tools for the sustained, focused development and study of the new human-technology paradigm, and; 3) establish a central point of engagement for stakeholders and external communities. This project will foster a new dialogue regarding the evolution of the human-technology relationship. Tangible outcomes from the planning process will include social media networking platforms, a central collaboration and dissemination website, and surveys to gauge stakeholder commitment to and refinement of the symbiotic model of human-technology evolution. Successful realization of a symbiotic human-technology paradigm requires a transdisciplinary approach to address significant scientific, technical, ethical, and social challenges. The transdisciplinary model of the ERC for Human Fusions has a technical core addressing anthropocentric technology, multisensory human interfaces, and connection infrastructure. Expanding around this are disciplines to address ethical questions of symbiotic technology, regulatory frameworks to support the ethical principles, entrepreneurial models to introduce new technology, and sociology to understand how symbiotic technologies impact society. These are highly integrated such that each is integral to the development and understanding of the other. The potential ERC will provide leadership, intellectual resources, the establishment of world-class facilities for responsible and effective scientific discovery, technological innovation, and resources in the new symbiotic sciences for education, research and development and translation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Humans and technology are inextricably intertwined. The relationship between humans and technology is evolving at an expanding rate in areas such as virtual and augmented reality. Advances in medical technology, and particularly neural engineering have shown that direct connection to the human nervous system is possible and can be beneficial in areas such as spinal cord injury, Parkinson?s disease, limb loss, and many others. This technology, however, more broadly represents a fundamental shift in the human-technology relationship. Since the first humans picked up a stone over 100,000 years ago, humans have used tools. We pick them up, hold them in our hands, tap on the screen, wear them on our body, sit in them, and many other variations. Traditional technology relies on the natural human senses and muscles for operation. However, by directly connection to the nervous system, it is possible to bypass the human sensors and muscles to directly interact with the brain. Thus, the technology becomes an extension of one?s own body. Technology becomes incorporated into the sense of self. We are now on the cusp of changing the paradigm from humans using technology to humas incorporating technology. The power of this is demonstrated by a person with an amputated limb that now connects to his prosthesis through a direct neural link. Without the link, he refers to his prosthesis as a tool at the end of his limb. When we turn on the connect, he says, "...it is my hand."

The Human Fusions Institute (HFI) is created to study and responsibly advance this new relationship between humans and technology. The vision is to create a thriving, just, and connected world through symbiotic human-technology relations. The HFI mission is to scale human location, capability, and resilience. To accomplish this mission, however, there are many scientific advances required. Further, to responsibly accomplish this mission with a human-centered focus, we must not only focus on the technological aspects of the mission, but also incorporate ethics, sociology, legal, medical, phenomenological, artistic, and humanitarian aspects from the beginning. The is the purpose of the Human Fusions Institute. This NSF planning grant supported the planning and development of the infrastructure and teams to achieve this vision in a transdisciplinary approach that is not simply technologically advanced, but also inclusive, principled, and secure. In addition to the scientific development, it is necessary to develop new educational curriculum to teach the future generations how to develop, operate, maintain, and thrive in this new human-technology paradigm. The goal is to shrink cultural, economic, and ethnic divides. This includes inclusive design, education, and research.

Through the execution of this planning grant, the mission, vision, values, operations, and team of the Human Fusion Institute have been carefully considered and developed. We have established a multi-institutional and multidisciplinary team. This team has created the first nation-wide infrastructure that was demonstrated to connect a human in Cleveland directly to robotic systems in California such that the person in Cleveland actual felt like they were in California. When they, as the robot, grabbed a banana in Los Angeles, they could feel that banana in Cleveland.

Through the planning grant, the HFI team held several workshops with many investigators from different disciplines across the arts, sciences, medicine, humanities, business, and engineering. The ideas from this diverse group of thinkers were combined into the mission and operations of the HFI. The HFI is organized into three major focus areas, which are Healthcare; Space/Industry/Military; and Education/Social/Gaming. We have held workshops in each of these areas to understand use cases, needs, and requirements where the Human Fusions approach can make a positive impact. We have created several portals to convey our information and directions to the public, including our website (https://www.humanfusions.org), Twitter (https://www.twitter.com/humanfusions), YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWnQF74xHkximSnPnoyHIlw) and LinkedIn (https://www.linkedin.com/company/humanfusions) sites. The team consisting of collaborators from Case Western Reserve University, University of California-Los Angeles, Cleveland State University, University of Wyoming, and University of Colorado-Boulder created a robotic avatar system and showed that we could connect across the country. As part of this effort, we developed an internet infrastructure that will eventually be made available for all to safely and effectively connect directly between humans and technology.

The planning grant has led to a significant, committed working team with a committed mission and vision, the foundational technology for continued development, organizational structure and operation, public facing information portals, and a solid foundation for continued study, development, workforce development, and ethical guidelines for the future development of the human-technology relationship for a just, thriving, and connected community.
